text: Hebrews chapter number two, last week we started this lesson, we ought to listen up. We've been dealing with this subject matter here on Wednesday evenings, doing what we ought to do, and just because we know what we ought to do doesn't mean we do what we ought to do. And last week we started with this thought of we ought to listen up, and I knew, and I said from the start that I wasn't confident that we'd get through all of the material last week, and we certainly did not. And so tonight's kind of part two of that same lesson. I'm going to very quickly give an overview of what we looked at last week in case you were not here, and then we'll get into the follow-up this evening. But we look at Hebrews chapter two and verse number one, the Bible says, therefore we ought to give the more earnest heed to the things which we have heard, lest at any time we should let them slip. For if the word spoken by angels was steadfast, and every transgression and disobedience received, a just recompense of reward, how shall we escape if we neglect so great salvation, which at the first began to be spoken by the Lord, and was confirmed unto us by them that heard Him, God also bearing them witness, both with signs and wonders, and with divers miracles and gifts of the Holy Ghost, according to His own will. And we focus on that first statement of the verse, number one, therefore we ought to give the more earnest heed to the things which we have heard. He says this, lest at any time we should let them slip, and we spoke about this idea of giving the more earnest heed, that's why I've titled it We Ought to Listen Up, and we said that we see that, therefore, to begin verse number one of chapter two, and we need to determine why is it there? What is it that was given to us in chapter one that is so important that he concludes, he reaches this conclusion that we ought to pay attention, we ought to give the more earnest heed, and so we went back to chapter one last week, we talked about the fact that the book of Hebrews deals with the subject matter throughout the book, a theme, that Christ is better, He is superior, in chapter one He deals with being superior to the angels, but we find that the book begins in verse number one that says, God, who at sundry times and in divers manners spake in time past unto the fathers by the prophets, but, notice verse number two, hath in these last days spoken unto us by His Son, whom He hath appointed heir of all things, by whom also He made the worlds, who being the brightness of His glory, and the express image of His person, and upholding all things by the word of His power, when He had by Himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the majesty on high. Now if those three verses don't make you want to shout and rejoice, I'm not sure what will, and the reality is that we serve a great God, we have a wonderful Savior, He is worthy of our worship and of our praise, and God reveals here that yes, He spoke, and we understand all scriptures given by inspiration of God, and is profitable, and just because if you have in your Bible, some people have a red letter edition Bible, listen, the red letters aren't more inspired than the other words, because all scripture is given by inspiration of God, but it is something when God in flesh came to earth, and He walked among them, and He spoke, remember I said this, that those that heard Him often would say, no man spake like this man. He speaks with power and with authority, and that's because He's God, He is God in flesh, and we find that the multitudes would come to hear Him, they would hear as they did in Mark chapter number two, that it was noise, that He was in the city, and all people, they wanted to go and hear Him, and they came, and they surrounded the house, there was no room for anyone to enter in, because there was such a great group of people, and you find throughout His earthly ministry, there were many that wanted to hear Him, and He spoke with authority. I'm thankful this evening that we have the scriptures, that we have the word of God, and we found last week that we said this, that we need to recognize the danger, the danger of what? Well, the danger of not hearing, the danger of not giving the more earnest heed, as the scriptures say here, the danger of not listening up, the danger of neglecting personal Bible reading, of missing church services, of not hearing the truth that God wants us to hear. We said this, the word hear and understanding of giving a, to that which we have heard and that idea of hearing is not just to hear, but to hear with the purpose of doing, with the intent of obeying. It's similar to what Samuel was told to say from Eli, speak, Lord, for thy servant heareth. And the idea was that he was listening, hearing, with the intent of obeying. I'm going to obey, I'm going to apply, I'm going to take heed to what you have said. And so we deal with, and we looked at a number of passages of scripture last week, dealing with the fact that God has been faithful. God has been faithful to give his word. We study the Old Testament, we read multiple times how that God sent prophets and God gave his word, but the people would not hear. Can I tell you this evening that God has been faithful to preserve this book? I am so thankful that God has preserved the Bible, that we can have in our hands today, tonight a, the copy of God's precious word. The truth of inspiration is so important for us to understand and it's so foundational that we understand that scripture, all scripture is given by inspiration of God. It's God breathed, but I want you to know this evening that inspiration without preservation doesn't really help any of us today. Because the originals are no longer with us, but God promised that he would preserve his word. And can I tell you that God always does what he says he will do and God has providentially preserved his word and we have this evening the word, we have the scriptures and what a blessing. I think about Paul, even as he would write to Timothy and he says that from a child thou hast heard the holy scriptures, thou hast known the holy scriptures, which are able to make thee wise unto salvation. No, Timothy didn't have the originals, but Timothy had the copies of the copies of the copies that were from the originals. And Paul said that that was scripture, that was God's word. He says to those as he's concluding that he's writing and giving some instruction, he says, bring these things to me, but especially the parchments. Why? Because he wanted to have those scriptures and I'm so thankful this evening. And so if we understand the danger, if we recognize, acknowledge the danger and we're dealing with the subject matter of we ought to listen up, then I believe, and what we'll focus on studying this evening is how do we learn to listen? How do we develop a plan for hearing, for listening, for the voice of God? I made a statement a couple of weeks ago on Sunday evening as I preached about Elijah that he heard the voice of the Lord. We need to get in a place where we hear the voice of the Lord, that we understand that as we open the precious pages of this book, that God is speaking to me as an individual, that God loves me, that God has a message for me and I approach it that way. And so how do we come to this place that we are going to, as we read here, we ought to give the more earnest heed to the things which we have heard, less than any time we should let them slip. Is it just going to be this, I'm going to work harder? No, I believe that we need to develop a plan. And I'm going to share a few things with you this evening that I hope would be a help for you. And the first thought is this, it's four simple thoughts, this is not an exhaustive plan for how we can develop this plan of learning to listen, but the first thought this evening is that we must remember the authority of God's word. We must remember the authority of God's word. I want you to think about this, what we believe about the Bible, what we believe about the book that you're holding in your hands this evening, will impact how you approach it. If you just, listen, people have the idea, you can read articles online, you can listen to people that will stand up and they'll speak for many, many lengths of time and hours and they'll say this is not the word of God, this is just man's words about God. Can I tell you this evening, if this is just man's words about God, it's really not that helpful because you can have your opinion about God and I can have my opinion about God and so on and so forth, but I'm thankful this evening that God said that he was going to give the word and that all scripture is given by inspiration of God, that he providentially preserved it, and it is God's word, and it's not man just writing about what they think about God, it is God who is the creator of the universe telling us who he is. And that's awesome. And when we understand that this word, this Bible, that it's profitable, when we understand that it's going to produce fruit, that it's going to be effective, it works in us. Listen, I know this evening, you're here on a Wednesday evening at church, you've read the Bible, you know that God's word is effectual, that it works in your heart, the entrance of thy words giveth light, and what a joy to know the truth of this book, and we must remember the authority. Now, I know that today, the idea of letter writing is kind of not as popular as it once was because we have so many other means of communication. But I want you to know that, and most of us here this evening, we remember when writing a letter and dropping it in the box was the only way to communicate with people on a regular basis. I mean, it used to be that they charged you by the minute to make phone calls. You remember that. You're old enough, just as I am, to remember when you had to pay per minute to make those phone calls. And so you could drop those letters in the mail. I remember while we're in college, my kids, they crack me up. They say, well, how old were you when you got a cell phone? Much older than you are. And by the way, I paid for it when I got it, amen? And the reality is that we didn't have cell phones. And so I'd go into the little mail room where we went to college, and I'd always go in to look at that box to see if there was, I didn't care if there was a graded report in there, if there was some note from the dean in there. No, I was looking for a note from Holly. And if she had a note put in there, and it was in there, guess what I did with that note? I just set it aside and ignored it. No, I read it. And guess how many times I read it? Multiple. I didn't just read it one time. Sometimes you try to read between the lines. You know what I'm saying? You try to figure out, I wonder what she really means by that. I wonder, and so on and so forth. And you can understand, listen, this book is from the God of the universe, from our God, who loves us with an everlasting love, who wants to communicate with us, and he's given it to us. And when I remember what this book is, when I remember that this book is like no other book, I have books all over my house, I got books in my library, I got books on my desk, I got them in my drawer on my desk, I got books all over the place, but there's no book that I enjoy reading as much as I enjoy reading this book. There's no other book. Listen, if I'm only gonna have time to read one book a day, it's gonna be this one. It's not going to be something else. It's not gonna be some news or some whatever periodical. No, this book is from by God to me as his child. And I believe that when we come with that approach, it's going to really help us to learn, to listen, to have that ear to hear what God has for me. Why? Because God's speaking to me. I understand that as we study the scriptures, it's important to have proper hermeneutics and to interpret the scriptures properly and to understand who the letter or the book was written to in the time and so on and so forth. But this book is a divine book. This book carries with it not only a message to the original hearers, but it carries with it a message to me as God's child today. And that's amazing. And so we come from that position. When I come from that position, it leads me to my second thought this evening, that I must then desire to hear from God. Let me say this, not only desiring, but expecting to hear from God. I think about this. I have had the opportunity in recent days to be at conferences and hear folks preach. I don't hear a ton of preaching because I often am preaching, but I do listen to some preaching. I have opportunity to go to some conferences. Of course, Sunday night, Brother Damastus preached. And man, when I come to church, I'm expecting to hear from God. When I open my Bible to read each morning, I'm expecting, I'm desiring to hear something from God. If I don't have that desire, if I don't have that expectation, then I'm not really probably gonna hear from God.
